Question :

Say you're doing analytics for a website. You need to write a function that returns the percentage growth in the total number of users relative to a specified number of years ago.

Your function percentage\_growth() should take two arguments as input:

num\_users = Python list with the total number of users each year. So num\_users[0] is the total number of users in the first year, num\_users[1] is the total number of users in the second year, and so on. The final entry in the list gives the total number of users in the most recently completed year.\

yrs\_ago = number of years to go back in time when calculating the growth percentage\

For instance, say \

num\_users = [920344, 1043553, 1204334, 1458996, 1503323, 1593432, 1623463, 1843064, 1930992, 2001078].

if yrs\_ago = 1, we want the function to return a value of about 0.036. This corresponds to a percentage growth of approximately 3.6%, calculated as (2001078 - 1930992)/1930992.

if years\_ago = 7, we would want to return approximately 0.66. This corresponds to a percentage growth of approximately 66%, calculated as (2001078 - 1204334)/1204334.

Your coworker sent you a draft of a function, but it doesn't seem to be doing the correct calculation. Can you figure out what has gone wrong and make the needed changes?


```

def embeding(data, vector):
    embs = []
    for sentence in data: # data is a list of sentences
        words = sentence.split()
        temp = np.zeros(300) # 300 is the dimension of each word vector

        if len(words) < 1:
            embs.append(temp) # If sentence is empty then default is full of 0

        for word in words:
            if word in vector:
                temp += vector[word]
            else:
```

```
class SentimentCNN(nn.Module):
    def \_\_init\_\_(self, embed\_model, vocab\_size, embedding\_dim, num\_filters, kernel\_sizes, output\_size, drop\_prob):
        super(SentimentCNN, self).__init__()
        # layers
        self.embedding_layer = nn.Embedding(vocab_size, embedding_dim)
        self.embedding_layer.weight = nn.Parameter(torch.from_numpy(embed_model.vectors))  # all vectors

        # cnn
        self.convs_1d_layers = nn.ModuleList([
            nn.Conv2d(1, num_filters, (k, embedding_dim), padding=(k - 2, 0))
            for k in kernel_sizes])

        # fc
        self.fc_layer = nn.Linear(len(kernel_sizes) * num_filters, output_size)

        # 4. dropout and sigmoid layers

        self.activation = nn.Sigmoid()

    def conv\_and\_pool(self, x, conv):
        """
 Convolutional + max pooling layer
 """
        # squeeze last dim to get size: (batch\_size, num\_filters, conv\_seq\_length)
        # conv\_seq\_length will be ~ 200
        x = torch.nn.ReLU()(conv(x)).squeeze(3)

        # 1D pool over conv\_seq\_length
        # squeeze to get size: (batch\_size, num\_filters)
        x_max = torch.nn.functional.max_pool1d(x, x.size(2)).squeeze(2)
        return x_max

    def forward(self, x):
        embeds = self.embedding_layer(x)  # (batch\_size, seq\_length, embedding\_dim)
        embeds = embeds.unsqueeze(1)
        conv_results = [self.conv_and_pool(embeds, conv) for conv in self.convs_1d_layers]
        x = torch.cat(conv_results, 1)
        x = self.dropout(x)
        logit = self.fc_layer(x)
        out = self.activation(logit)
        return out

    def predict(self, X\_test):
        return torch.round(self.forward(X_test).squeeze())
```

486019.content:
## **Introduction**

The documentation of a project, process, user guide, or package is one way to ensure that everything that was planned has been implemented and is in place. A detailed document is not only essential for the end user but also for technical teams which need to refer to the document quite often. It is also one of the most boring, time-consuming activities but also the most important aspect of the project and a good investment for the future. A standard approach with the right kind of tools would go a long way in generating documents that are easy to use, search, navigate, and reuse. Python libraries like Sphinx and Mkdocs will let us generate these documents automatically from the code with no additional effort on documentation. 

## **Overview of Sphinx**

Sphinx is open source, written in Python, and was primarily built for Python documentation but it also supports a wide range of languages. Sphinx uses reStructuredText markup language by default which is specially designed for technical documentation. The easy-to-configure themes and extensions make it the most popular documentation library.

Here is the snapshot of the document generated - [GitHub](https://github.com/amitvkulkarni/Blogs/tree/main/Sphinx%20Vs%20MkDocs%20%7C%20Powerful%20Documentation%20Using%20Python)\

![](https://www.googleapis.com/download/storage/v1/b/kaggle-forum-message-attachments/o/inbox%2F4876670%2Fea3872cfcb9e52886c746ffbc72a41d5%2Fsphinx-home-2.png?generation=1711175697375120&alt=media)

## **Overview of MkDocs**

MkDocs is a simple-to-use static site generator based on markdown. It is written in Python but is language-agnostic and a good choice of technical documentation where speed and simplicity are important. As it is a markdown, one can preview the content on the go. A good collection of themes and its easy customization make it a more attractive option for writing and building documentation. When coupled with mkdocstrings, it is a powerful tool for document generation from sources.

Here is the snapshot of the document generated - [GitHub](https://github.com/amitvkulkarni/Blogs/tree/main/Sphinx%20Vs%20MkDocs%20%7C%20Powerful%20Documentation%20Using%20Python)\

![](https://www.googleapis.com/download/storage/v1/b/kaggle-forum-message-attachments/o/inbox%2F4876670%2Fc69df01eea6f900ca464a706df3fe643%2Fmkdocs-home.png?generation=1711175738447160&alt=media)

## **Conclusion**

There are various ways to document a project or package and everyone has their preference depending on the nature of the project and its complexity. We have explored and learned two most popular libraries in Python for auto-generated documents. Sphinx is the most popular and is widely used, most of the Python package documentation is built from Sphinx. The mkdocs, on the other hand, uses markdown, and I find it easier to configure and use. The combination of mkdocs and mkdocstrings would generate the same result as that of the sphinx. I highly recommend exploring and leveraging the power of both frameworks.

## **Official documentation for reference**

<https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/index.html>\

<https://www.mkdocs.org/>

## **Quick start code on [GitHub](https://github.com/amitvkulkarni/Blogs/tree/main/Sphinx%20Vs%20MkDocs%20%7C%20Powerful%20Documentation%20Using%20Python)**

Hey everyone,

We've all seen them - those fantastic notebooks that are not only informative but also a joy to explore. But what exactly makes a notebook stand out from the crowd?

Let's share our thoughts and experiences to create a community guide to crafting awesome notebooks! Here are some aspects to consider:

**Clarity and Structure:**\

Is the notebook well-organized, with clear sections and easy navigation?\

Are explanations concise and understandable, even for beginners?\

**Code Readability:**\

Is the code well-formatted, commented, and easy to follow?\

Does it adhere to best practices for maintainability and reusability?\

**Data Exploration and Visualization:**\

Does the notebook effectively explore the data, highlighting key insights and trends?\

Are visualizations clear, informative, and visually appealing?\

**Model Selection and Evaluation:**\

Does the notebook justify the choice of models used?\

Are evaluation metrics explained and results clearly presented?\

**Innovation and Exploration:**\

Does the notebook showcase unique approaches or creative solutions?\

Does it encourage further exploration and experimentation?

By combining our experiences, we can create a valuable resource for everyone , helping us all craft notebooks that are informative, engaging, and contribute to the collective knowledge pool.

Looking forward to a lively discussion!\

485050.content:
![](https://www.googleapis.com/download/storage/v1/b/kaggle-forum-message-attachments/o/inbox%2F17590358%2F768ea66db659ece931d3926db53604f4%2F1.jpeg?generation=1710840281688938&alt=media)

### Introduction to Exploratory Data Analysis

Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) is a crucial step in the data science process that involves analyzing and visualizing data to uncover patterns, relationships, and insights. It serves as the foundation for building predictive models and making informed decisions based on data.

### EDA in Data Science

In the realm of data science, EDA plays a pivotal role in understanding the structure of datasets, identifying outliers, missing values, and trends. By conducting EDA, aspiring data scientists can gain a deeper understanding of the underlying patterns within the data before diving into more complex modeling techniques.

### Conducting Effective EDA

To conduct effective EDA, aspiring data scientists should start by exploring descriptive statistics such as mean, median, standard deviation, and visualizations like histograms, scatter plots, and box plots. These techniques help in identifying anomalies and outliers that may impact the analysis.

### Tools and Technologies for Performing EDA

There are various tools and technologies available for performing EDA efficiently. Popular tools like Python libraries such as Pandas, NumPy, Matplotlib, Seaborn along with R programming language provide a wide range of functions for conducting exploratory analysis effectively.

### Common Challenges Faced During EDA

Despite its importance, EDA comes with its own set of challenges. Some common challenges include dealing with missing values effectively, handling large datasets efficiently, selecting relevant variables for analysis among others. Overcoming these challenges requires a combination of technical skills and domain knowledge.

### Conclusion

Exploratory Data Analysis is an indispensable part of the data science workflow that empowers aspiring data scientists to derive meaningful insights from raw data. By mastering the art of EDA using appropriate tools and techniques while addressing common challenges encountered during analysis will enable them to unlock valuable insights hidden within datasets.
485050.title: Begginer Guide to Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) for Aspiring Data Scientists

315696.content:
Hi everyone,

We are sharing a series of notebooks to help Kagglers to get started with the machine learning frameworks JAX and FLAX.

**Intro to JAX**

[JAX](https://github.com/google/jax) is a framework which is used for high-performance numerical computing and machine learning research developed by [Google Research](https://research.google/). It allows you to build Python applications with a NumPy-consistent API that specializes in differentiating, vectorizing, parallelizing, and compiling to GPU/TPU Just-In-Time. JAX was designed with performance and speed as a first priority, and is natively compatible with common machine learning accelerators such as [GPUs](https://www.kaggle.com/docs/efficient-gpu-usage) and [TPUs](https://www.kaggle.com/docs/tpu). Large ML models can take ages to train -- you might be interested in using JAX for applications where speed and performance are particularly important!

**When to use JAX vs TensorFlow?**

[TensorFlow](https://www.tensorflow.org/guide) is a mature product, with a rich and fully-featured ecosystem, capable of supporting most every use case a machine learning practitioner might have (e.g. [TFLite](https://www.tensorflow.org/lite) for on-device inference computing, [TFHub](https://tfhub.dev/) for sharing pre-trained models, and many additional specialized applications as well). This type of broad mandate both contrasts and compliments JAX's philosophy, which is more narrowly focused on speed and performance. We recommend using JAX in situations where you do want to maximize speed and performance but you do not require any of the long tail of features and additional functionalities that only the [TensorFlow ecosystem](https://www.tensorflow.org/learn) can provide. 

**Intro to FLAX**

Just like [JAX](https://jax.readthedocs.io/en/latest/notebooks/quickstart.html) focuses on speed, other members of the JAX ecosystem are encouraged to specialize as well. For example, [Flax](https://flax.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) focuses on neural networks and [jgraph](https://github.com/deepmind/jraph) focuses on graph networks. 

[Flax](https://flax.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) is a JAX-based neural network library that was initially developed by Google Research's Brain Team (in close collaboration with the JAX team) but is now open source. If you want to train machine learning models on GPUs and TPUs at an accelerated speed, or if you have an ML project that might benefit from bringing together both [Autograd](https://github.com/hips/autograd) and [XLA](https://www.tensorflow.org/xla), consider using [Flax](https://flax.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) for your next project! [Flax](https://flax.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) is especially well-suited for projects that use large language models, and is a popular choice for cutting-edge [machine learning research](https://arxiv.org/search/?query=JAX&searchtype=all&abstracts=show&order=-announced_date_first&size=50).

**You can also use the JAX/FLAX framework in your notebooks to make submissions for the [Google OSS Expert prize](https://www.kaggle.com/google-oss-expert-prize) program.**

**How can I get started with JAX/FLAX?**

Here are some getting started notebooks on how to use JAX/FLAX with different dataset formats for training machine learning models. 

* [Digit Recognizer using JAX/FLAX (Toy image dataset)](https://www.kaggle.com/nilaychauhan/digit-recognizer-using-jax-flax)
* [Dog Breed Classification using JAX/FLAX (Image Dataset)](https://www.kaggle.com/nilaychauhan/dog-breed-classification-using-jax-and-flax)
* [Jigsaw toxic comment classification using JAX/FLAX (Text Dataset)](https://www.kaggle.com/nilaychauhan/jigsaw-toxic-comment-classification-using-jax-flax)
* [Cornell BirdCall classification using JAX/FLAX (Audio dataset)](https://www.kaggle.com/nilaychauhan/cornell-birdcall-audio-recognition-using-jax-flax)

Likewise, this recently launched [community competition](https://www.kaggle.com/c/goodreads-books-reviews-290312/overview) has both a large training dataset and a problem statement that benefits from fine-tuning a large language model -- it might be a great place to try out JAX as well!

**Disclaimer:**

**We recommend using [GPUs](https://www.kaggle.com/docs/efficient-gpu-usage) when working with JAX on Kaggle.** These notebooks are compatible with the v3-8 [TPUs](https://www.kaggle.com/docs/tpu) that are provided for free in [Kaggle Notebooks](https://www.kaggle.com/code/new), but JAX was optimized for the newly updated [TPU VM](https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/compute/introducing-cloud-tpu-vms) architecture which is not yet available on Kaggle.
315696.title: Getting Started with JAX/FLAX

2297706.content: That's great to hear that you're sharing notebooks to help others get started with JAX and FLAX! These frameworks offer powerful capabilities for high-performance numerical computing and machine learning research. JAX provides a NumPy-consistent API with a focus on speed, performance, and compatibility with GPUs and TPUs. It's a great choice when you prioritize efficiency and don't require the full range of features offered by TensorFlow. FLAX, on the other hand, is a JAX-based neural network library developed by Google Research's Brain Team. It specializes in neural networks and is particularly well-suited for projects involving large language models. It integrates both Autograd and XLA to enable accelerated training on GPUs and TPUs. To get started with JAX and FLAX, you can explore the provided notebooks that cover various dataset formats and machine learning tasks such as digit recognition, dog breed classification, toxic comment classification, and Cornell BirdCall classification. These notebooks will guide you through using JAX and FLAX in different scenarios, allowing you to gain hands-on experience. Additionally, there is a community competition that focuses on fine-tuning a large language model. It could be an excellent opportunity to apply JAX and FLAX in a practical problem-solving context. Please note that while JAX notebooks are compatible with v3-8 TPUs available on Kaggle for free, it's recommended to use GPUs for optimal performance. The JAX framework was optimized for the newly updated TPU VM architecture, which is not yet available on Kaggle. Best of luck with your JAX and FLAX exploration, and I hope your notebooks and contributions will help others in the Kaggle community!

2294786.content: It's important to consider the hardware requirements when working with JAX on platforms like Kaggle. While Kaggle provides free v3-8 TPUs, it's worth noting that JAX is optimized for the newly updated TPU VM architecture, which may not be available on Kaggle yet. In such cases, using GPUs can be a suitable alternative. Being aware of these hardware limitations helps ensure efficient and optimal performance while working with JAX on Kaggle.

486359.content:
**Hey, fellow Kagglers!** üôã‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è 

A few days back, I stumbled upon a thought-provoking discussion here about the interpretability of deep learning models, often referred to as "black boxes." In current times, deep learning is being increasingly used across various sectors, and understanding the workings of these models is becoming more and more crucial.

## Deep Learning via Explainable AI (XAI) üîÆ

Deep learning models can seem mysterious with their intricate layers and complex structures. Explainable AI (XAI) offers several approaches to shed light on their decision making processes.

* **LIME and SHAP:** are tools that explain individual predictions by attributing the prediction decision to each feature's contribution.\

**Lime Example**


```
import lime
from lime import lime_tabular
# For a model trained on X\_train
explainer = lime_tabular.LimeTabularExplainer(
    training_data=np.array(X_train),
    feature_names=X_train.columns,
    class_names=['Negative', 'Positive'],
    mode='classification')
exp = explainer.explain_instance(data_row=X_train.iloc[1], predict_fn=model.predict_proba)
exp.show_in_notebook(show_table=True)
content\_copy
```
**Sharp Example**


```
import shap
shap.initjs()
explainer = shap.TreeExplainer(model)
shap_values = explainer.shap_values(X_train)
shap.force_plot(explainer.expected_value[1], shap_values[1][0], X_train.iloc[0])
content\_copy
```
* **Feature Visualization:** This technique reveals which features are prioritized by the model, aiding in deciphering its focus.
* **Attention Mechanisms:** Originally from the NLP world, show what parts of the input data are most influential in the model's decisions.
* **Model Simplification:** Striving for simplicity, this approach attempts to make complex models more interpretable without significantly impacting their accuracy.
* **Interactive Visualization Tools:** By enabling the dynamic exploration of how input modifications alter outputs, these tools offer hands-on insights into model behavior.

## Trade-offs in Deep Learning Explainability ‚öñ

While seeking interpretability in deep learning, we encounter some trade-offs mentioned below:

* **Accuracy vs. Explainability:** Increasing a model's explainability can sometimes compromise its accuracy, a careful balance to maintain performance is essential.
* **Complexity of Interpretation Methods:** Some interpretability techniques can be intricate, challenging their practical application.
* **Contextual Relevance:** Explanations must resonate with domain-specific insights to be actionable and meaningful.

## Resources for Further Learning üìö

To delve deeper into the world of Explainable AI and interpretability in deep learning, check out the following resources:

* [Interpretable Machine Learning" by Christoph Molnar](https://christophm.github.io/interpretable-ml-book/). A comprehensive guide to making machine learning models interpretable.
* [Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI)](https://arxiv.org/abs/2006.00093). A detailed paper providing an extensive overview of XAI.
* [LIME GitHub Repository](https://github.com/marcotcr/lime)
* [SHAP GitHub Repository](https://github.com/slundberg/shap)
* [A Survey on Attention Mechanisms in Deep Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2103.16775)

# Concluding Thoughts üí≠

Understanding the "black box" of deep learning is crucial for fostering trust and ethical integration in real-world applications. Prioritising explainability along with accuracy lets us fully leverage the potential of deep learning, enhancing efficiency and ensuring the outcomes align with ethical standards. I am excited to hear your tips on tricks for understanding and interpretability of deep learning models!

‚ú®**Best Wishes!** ‚ú®

485955.content:
Setting up your data science environment involves installing Python, Jupyter Notebooks, and other essential tools that will be the backbone of your projects. This is a series, so every *few days* I plan to release new content and how-to guides to enrich your journey.

# Installing Python

* First, visit the [Python website](https://python.org) and download the latest version of Python for your operating system.\

![](https://www.googleapis.com/download/storage/v1/b/kaggle-forum-message-attachments/o/inbox%2F19197548%2Fdd96da875db6158adde51c0bb8c61558%2FScreen_Shot_2020-07-16_at_11.webp?generation=1711139286365103&alt=media)
* Next, run the installer and follow the instructions. Ensure you check the box that says ‚ÄúAdd Python to PATH‚Äù during installation to make Python accessible from the command line.

# Setting Up Jupyter Notebooks

Jupyter Notebooks provide an interactive coding environment, allowing you to combine live code, visualizations, and markdown notes in a single document.\

![](https://www.googleapis.com/download/storage/v1/b/kaggle-forum-message-attachments/o/inbox%2F19197548%2Faee847b76632a98a63527738d7222f6b%2F02_new_notebook.webp?generation=1711139504098043&alt=media)

* Open your command line (Command Prompt on Windows, Terminal on macOS and Linux) and install Jupyter using Python's package manager pip:


```
pip install notebook
content\_copy
```
* After installation, run the following command in your command line to start Jupyter Notebook


```
jupyter notebook
content\_copy
```
This command will open Jupyter Notebook in your default web browser, ready for you to start creating new notebooks.

# Basic Setup

Create a dedicated folder on your computer for your data science projects. This will help you keep your datasets, scripts, and notebooks organized.\

![](https://www.googleapis.com/download/storage/v1/b/kaggle-forum-message-attachments/o/inbox%2F19197548%2Ff19f953c0e7434b4b6a5150277ca60d3%2Fpython-virtual-envs1.webp?generation=1711139586853920&alt=media)

* Based on my previous experience, it‚Äôs a good practice to use virtual environments for your projects to manage dependencies efficiently. You can create a virtual environment using:


```
python -m venv myenv
content\_copy
```
* Next, install the core libraries for data analysis and visualization. With your virtual environment activated, install pandas, NumPy, Matplotlib, and Seaborn using pip:


```
pip install pandas numpy matplotlib seaborn
content\_copy
```
# My advice

* Familiarize yourself with the Jupyter Notebook interface. Practice creating new notebooks, writing and executing code, and using markdown for notes.
* Consider installing Git for version control and collaboration. Git allows you to track changes, revert to previous states, and collaborate with others on projects.
* Once you're comfortable with the basics, explore additional tools and libraries that can help with your specific needs, such as scikit-learn for machine learning, or TensorFlow and PyTorch for deep learning projects.

Don‚Äôt hesitate to experiment with your setup, and remember, the best way to learn is by doing ‚ò∫Ô∏è



---

If you learnt something, don‚Äôt forget to drop an upvote to show your support. Additionally, if you have any comments or suggestions, make sure you put them in the comments.

Thanks for reading and follow me [@sahirmaharajj](https://www.kaggle.com/sahirmaharajj) for daily tips.
485955.title: Data Driven #2: Setting Up Your Data Science Environment

485874.content:
In the ever-evolving landscape of technology, StackOverflow, once the pinnacle for developers seeking answers, faced a formidable challenge with the emergence of generative AI products like ChatGPT, Gemini, Perplexity, etc. What appeared as a threat soon transformed into an opportunity, showcasing StackOverflow's resilience and adaptability amidst technological disruption.

During its golden age, StackOverflow stood unchallenged as the go-to platform for developers worldwide. However, the landscape shifted with the rise of generative AI, particularly ChatGPT, which posed a significant challenge to StackOverflow's dominance. The platform experienced a decline in popularity, leading to a noticeable drop in user engagement and posting activity.

Responding to this existential threat, StackOverflow initially implemented a reactionary measure by banning all generative AI. This move, while perhaps driven by a fear of obsolescence or a misunderstanding of AI's potential, reflected the initial resistance to change.

However, StackOverflow quickly recognized the need for a strategic shift. Within a remarkably short span of seven months, the company reversed its stance, lifting the AI ban and introducing OverflowAI, a groundbreaking initiative that embraced generative AI technology.

The decision to integrate AI into its platform marked a pivotal moment for StackOverflow. With OverflowAI, the platform underwent a remarkable transformation, leveraging the power of AI to enhance user experience and functionality:

1. **Enhanced Search Functionality**: The search feature, powered by generative AI, underwent a significant upgrade, delivering more accurate and relevant search results, thereby improving the overall quality of user interactions.
2. **Virtual Assistant Integration**: A virtual assistant was seamlessly integrated into the platform, assisting users in formulating precise and detailed questions, thus facilitating more effective knowledge exchange and problem-solving.
3. **IDE Integration**: Recognizing the diverse needs of developers, StackOverflow introduced an OverflowAI plugin for Visual Studio, enabling developers to seamlessly access StackOverflow's vast repository of knowledge directly from their integrated development environment (IDE), streamlining the development workflow.

StackOverflow's journey serves as a testament to the importance of adaptability in navigating technological disruptions. Rather than resisting change, StackOverflow embraced innovation, demonstrating the value of reassessment, adaptation, and adoption in staying relevant and competitive in a rapidly evolving landscape.

In conclusion, StackOverflow's transition from perceiving generative AI as a threat to embracing it as an opportunity underscores the transformative power of strategic evolution. By embracing technological advancements, StackOverflow not only revitalized its platform but also reaffirmed its position as a pioneering force in the developer community. As we continue to witness the relentless march of technological progress, StackOverflow's journey serves as a guiding beacon, inspiring organizations to embrace change and harness innovation to thrive in the face of uncertainty.

485799.content:
**What is Plotly Dash?**\

Dash is an open-source Python framework used for building analytical web applications and is built on top of Flask, Plotly.js, and React.js. Its simple and easy-to-use framework lets data scientist put their complex model behind the app and the interactive interface enables the users to make business decisions that are backed by data and derived from models.

**What is Dash AG Grid?**\

The Dash AG Grid is the newest addition to the current family of Dash components and widgets. It is an open-source library for building complex data tables with features like sorting, filtering, and pagination. The library is designed for high-performance and large data sets. It is a fully-featured and enterprise-ready grid component that can be used in Dash applications. There is an open-source and also enterprise version(licensed) that has more features.

**What is Dash DataTable?**\

Dash DataTable is an interactive table component designed for viewing, editing, and exploring large datasets. This component was written from scratch in React.js specifically for the Dash community. The Dash DataTable has been a popular choice for representing data in tabular form due to its customizable features like colors, size, formats, and style. It lets users explore data in more depth at the tabular level.

**Benefits of using Dash AG Grid**\

AG Grid is a feature-rich data grid that offers enterprise-grade features like filtering, sorting, grouping, and tree data. It is also one of the fastest data grids on the market, making it ideal for large data sets. In addition, AG Grid is easily integrated with other web technologies, making it a powerful tool for Dash applications. There were features that we implemented in AG Grid that were not possible in DataTable like resizing columns, rearranging columns, and rows, and built-in filtering options similar to that of MS Excel.

* The grid‚Äôs features are well suited to the Dash architecture
* The grid is highly configurable so that you can customize it to your needs
* The grid is easy to use, so you can get up and running quickly
* The grid is reliable and well-supported, so you can be confident in its stability

![](https://www.googleapis.com/download/storage/v1/b/kaggle-forum-message-attachments/o/inbox%2F4876670%2F7d06806173ee77a8c66c5dfe08073d96%2Fpreview.png?generation=1711090319394530&alt=media)

At the end of the day, AG Grid is a powerful tool that can speed up your development process. It is easy to use and easy to integrate into your existing dashboards. If you are looking for a tool to help you create beautiful and interactive data visualizations, AG Grid is a great option.

**Official Documentation for reference**\

<https://dash.plotly.com/datatable>\

<https://dash.plotly.com/dash-ag-grid>

**The example code to get started**: [GitHub](https://github.com/amitvkulkarni/Blogs/tree/main/Dash%20AG%20Grid)

293861.content:
Hi Kagglers,

**Recently [Kaggle](https://www.kaggle.com/) released a feature [schedule notebooks](https://www.kaggle.com/product-feedback/284587) to schedule your notebooks to run automatically**. Using this, you can schedule your notebook to run daily/weekly/monthly and likewise any datasets that are created from scheduled notebook outputs can be set to automatically update whenever a new version of the notebook is saved. Furthermore, you can also schedule your notebooks to rerun whenever the datasets they are attached to get updated.

### How do I use scheduled updates?

1. In the settings menu of the notebook editor, schedule the notebook to update either daily, weekly, monthly, or in response to the underlying dataset getting updated.
2. In the metadata section of a dataset that was created directly from a Kaggle Notebook Output File, select "**Keep dataset in sync with new notebook versions**".

Some limitations include:

* Only **CPU** notebooks can be scheduled (not GPU/TPU).
* **5 Private** and **15 Public** notebooks can be scheduled at any given time.
* Schedules expire after a **maximum** of **10 runs** after which they need to be reset.
* For **dataset update triggers** , scheduled notebooks run at most once per day.

### Why do we need the scheduled updates?

There are plenty of datasets which update on a daily or weekly or monthly basis, and previously notebooks depending on these datasets had to be re-run manually every time that the underlying datasets were updated. For example , the [USA COVID-19 Vaccinations](https://www.kaggle.com/paultimothymooney/usa-covid19-vaccinations) dataset updates daily and notebook authors may want to schedule their notebooks to run every time that a new dataset version is published. Likewise, you can schedule notebooks to update on their own [even if they are not attached to any underlying datasets](https://www.kaggle.com/brsdincer/climatic-eye-of-isci-disaster-tracking-panel).

**You can also use this feature to automatically re-run notebooks that create, maintain, and update new datasets as well**. For example, the [Reliance Stock Prices with News Sentiment üìà](https://www.kaggle.com/yashvi/reliancestockandnewsdata)  dataset gets updated daily as a result of this [scheduled notebook](https://www.kaggle.com/yashvi/reliance-stock-prices-with-news-sentiment) , fetching daily stock market data of Reliance and its daily news articles and creating a derived dataset which contains **news sentiment**. We can use this [generated dataset](https://www.kaggle.com/yashvi/reliancestockandnewsdata) and study the stock market behavior and plan buy or sell strategies accordingly.

Likewise, the [Kaggle Feedback Comments](https://www.kaggle.com/yashvi/kaggle-feedback-comments) dataset gets updated daily as a result of [this scheduled notebook](https://www.kaggle.com/yashvi/feedback-on-feature-launch-part-1-2-transform/notebook) (runs daily) , which is taking "**Feature Launch/Update**" forum posts from [meta-kaggle](https://www.kaggle.com/kaggle/meta-kaggle) dataset , transforming it and creating a new [derived dataset](https://www.kaggle.com/yashvi/kaggle-feedback-comments) from the notebook outputs and [this notebook](https://www.kaggle.com/yashvi/feedback-on-feature-launch-part-2-2-analyze) analyzing kagglers reaction on feature launches/updates forum posts , scheduled to run whenever the [Kaggle Feedback Comments](https://www.kaggle.com/yashvi/kaggle-feedback-comments) dataset gets updated.

### Community examples

* Notebooks that are scheduled to re-run automatically in order to create, maintain, and keep updated a new or novel dataset


	+ <https://www.kaggle.com/yashvi/reliance-stock-prices-with-news-sentiment>
	+ <https://www.kaggle.com/yashvi/feedback-on-feature-launch-part-1-2-transform>
	+ <https://www.kaggle.com/mrisdal/fetch-scrabble-data-from-woogles-io>
	+ <https://www.kaggle.com/mrisdal/process-scrabble-data-from-woogles-io>
	+ <https://www.kaggle.com/bertnieuwenampsen/webscraping-top-movies-by-moviemeter-nl>
	+ <https://www.kaggle.com/rajkumarl/ruddit-comment-extraction>
	+ <https://www.kaggle.com/philmod/astor-wine-sales>
* Datasets that were created from the outputs of scheduled notebook runs


	+ <https://www.kaggle.com/yashvi/reliancestockandnewsdata/metadata>
	+ <https://www.kaggle.com/yashvi/kaggle-feedback-comments/metadata>
	+ <https://www.kaggle.com/mrisdal/scrabble-data-from-wooglesio/metadata>
	+ <https://www.kaggle.com/mrisdal/raw-wooglesio-games/metadata>
* Notebooks that are scheduled to re-run automatically in order to maintain an always-up-to-date data visualization


	+ <https://www.kaggle.com/yashvi/us-trending-videos-eda>
	+ <https://www.kaggle.com/yashvi/feedback-on-feature-launch-part-2-2-analyze>
	+ <https://www.kaggle.com/carlmcbrideellis/kaggle-in-numbers>
	+ <https://www.kaggle.com/brsdincer/climatic-eye-of-isci-disaster-tracking-panel>
	+ <https://www.kaggle.com/martinmalandro/usa-tx-covid-19-tracking>
	+ <https://www.kaggle.com/paultimothymooney/eda-on-covid-panel-updated-weekly>
* Notebooks that are scheduled to update whenever a new version of the underlying dataset is published


	+ <https://www.kaggle.com/kalilurrahman/nasdaq-100-stock-visualization-eda>
	+ <https://www.kaggle.com/kalilurrahman/nasdaq-stock-price-prediction-using-lstm/notebook>
	+ <https://www.kaggle.com/paultimothymooney/usa-covid19-vaccinations

2493251.content:
To create a pipeline of scheduled and triggered notebooks, follow these steps:

1. Choose a notebook environment.
2. Write your notebooks for specific tasks.
3. Use version control (e.g., Git).
4. Optionally containerize your notebooks (e.g., Docker).
5. Set up a scheduler for automated execution.
6. Write an automation script to call notebooks.
7. Create a trigger mechanism for on-demand execution.
8. Implement logging and monitoring.
9. Consider cloud orchestration services.
10. Thoroughly test and validate the pipeline.
11. Implement error handling.
12. Ensure security and access control.
13. Document your pipeline and metadata.
14. Perform regular maintenance and optimization.
15. Scale and deploy as needed

Wonderful findings [@yashvi](https://www.kaggle.com/yashvi) This is really great feature introduce by Kaggle, but there are few areas (mentioned below) where Kaggle needs to improve like other organisation works(like Databricks, Azure Databricks and many more). That will help us to improve a lot.

**Complexity**\

1) If i schedule a notebook if i will get an error i should informed over mail. if notebook's run is successful i should informed over email. Managing a pipeline of notebooks, especially when they have interdependencies, can become complex. Ensuring that notebooks are executed in the correct order and that data is passed effectively between them can be challenging.\

**Debugging**\

2)Debugging errors or issues in scheduled or triggered notebooks can be more challenging than debugging notebooks run interactively. Errors may not be immediately apparent, and diagnosing problems in a scheduled context can be time-consuming.\

**Version Control**\

3)Keeping track of changes and versions in a pipeline of notebooks can be more challenging than working with standalone notebooks. Maintaining proper version control and ensuring consistency across the pipeline is essential. **Connection with something like GIT Repo will be highly appreciated and much reliable**\

**API Limitations:**\

4)Kaggle's APIs have usage limitations. If your pipeline relies heavily on Kaggle's APIs for data or other interactions, you may run into API usage limits.

2413100.content:
Hi [@parthkapgate](https://www.kaggle.com/parthkapgate),

Your question is quite valid and not stupid at all. Scheduled updates and automatic reruns of notebooks can be incredibly useful for keeping datasets and visualizations up to date, but when it comes to predictive models, especially for stock prices, it does introduce some challenges and potential pitfalls.

**Model Evaluation:** As you pointed out, if a model is constantly updating itself with the latest data, it becomes difficult to assess its true predictive power. Ideally, you would want to train your model on a set of data, make predictions for a future period, and then compare those predictions to the actual outcomes once they are known. This helps you to understand how well your model is likely to perform in real-world scenarios.

**Overfitting:** Continually updating the model with new data carries the risk of overfitting the model to recent trends, which may not be representative of the longer-term trend. This can result in a model that is too sensitive to recent fluctuations and may not generalize well to future data.

**Manipulation:** As you noted, there is also a risk that someone could manipulate their model to match recent data too closely, either intentionally or unintentionally. This could result in a model that appears to have high predictive accuracy but actually performs poorly on new, unseen data.

**To mitigate these risks, it is important to have a robust model evaluation process in place. This could involve:**

* Splitting your data into a training set, a validation set, and a test set. The model is trained on the training set, its hyperparameters are tuned using the validation set, and its final performance is evaluated on the test set.
* Using cross-validation techniques, such as k-fold cross-validation, to assess the model's performance on different subsets of the data.
* Regularly assessing the model's performance on new data and comparing its predictions to actual outcomes. This can help to identify any deterioration in the model's performance and make necessary adjustments.
* Being cautious about how frequently you update your model and carefully considering whether new data genuinely contributes to improving the model's predictive power.

Remember, it's always important to strike a balance between updating your model to reflect new data and avoiding the risks of overfitting and manipulation. As a beginner, it's great that you are thinking about these issues and considering the potential implications of automatically updating your models.

2315014.content:
You would need to use scheduling capability of your operating system to [run `jupyter` from your command line](https://docs.jupyter.org/en/latest/running.html#using-a-command-line-interface). On [Linux (and on Mac I believe - I am not Mac user) it is `cron`](https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/scheduling-python-scripts-on-linux/) and in [Windows it can be done with Windows Task Scheduler](https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/schedule-python-script-using-windows-scheduler/).

As a bonus, you would have better granularity (by minute) and much more complex schedules. With Kaggle API you can actually trigger [the execution of Kaggle notebooks from these locally run schedulers](https://www.kaggle.com/discussions/product-feedback/371090).

2300586.content:
[@yashvi](https://www.kaggle.com/yashvi) platform:

Choose a platform that supports notebook execution and automation. Popular options include Jupyter Notebook, JupyterLab, or cloud-based platforms like Databricks or AWS Sagemaker.

Configure your environment: Install the software and dependencies required to run notebooks. This can be Python, Jupyter, and whatever library or package you use in your notebook.

Creating your notebooks: Create notebooks with the code you want to execute as part of your pipeline. These notebooks should be designed to run independently and perform specific tasks or analysis.

Define Triggers and Schedules : Define the execution of events or schedules that will trigger your notebooks. Triggers can be events such as data arriving at a specific location, API calls, or user action. Schedules can be defined so that the directory is run at specific times or for specific periods of time (e.g. daily, weekly, monthly).

Set up automation: Depending on the platform you choose, there are different ways to automate notebooks. Here are a few options:

Jupyter Notebook/JupyterLab: Use cron or integrated scheduling tools such as an external job scheduler (e.g., papermill with cron) to schedule the notebook's execution.\

Databricks: Use Databricks Jobs or Databricks Automation to schedule and trigger notebook processing.\

AWS Sagemaker: Set AWS Step Functions or AWS Lambda functions to schedule and trigger notebook operations.\

Configure notebook functions: Set settings for notebook functions, including input parameters, environment variables, and dependencies. Ensure notebooks are configured to store output files or communicate results as needed.

Monitoring and troubleshooting: Use logging and monitoring mechanisms to track the performance of your notes

2297710.content:
Creating a pipeline of scheduled and triggered notebooks can be a powerful way to automate your data processing and analysis workflows on Kaggle. By using scheduled updates, you can ensure that your notebooks run automatically at specified intervals or in response to dataset updates. Here's how you can set up and utilize this feature:

Schedule Notebooks:\

Open the notebook editor and go to the settings menu.\

Choose the desired frequency for your notebook updates: daily, weekly, monthly, or triggered by dataset updates.\

Note that currently only CPU notebooks can be scheduled, and there are limits on the number of scheduled notebooks (5 Private, 15 Public).

Keep Datasets in Sync:\

If you have created a dataset directly from a Kaggle Notebook Output File, you can select the option to keep the dataset in sync with new notebook versions.\

This ensures that whenever a new version of the notebook is saved, the dataset will be automatically updated.

It's important to be aware of some limitations:\

Scheduled notebooks on Kaggle run at most once per day for dataset update triggers.\

Scheduled notebooks have a maximum of 10 runs before they need to be reset.\

GPU/TPU notebooks cannot be scheduled at this time.

Scheduled updates can be beneficial in various scenarios:\

Automatically re-running notebooks that create, maintain, and update datasets.\

Keeping data visualizations always up-to-date by scheduling notebook runs.\

Updating notebooks whenever a new version of the underlying dataset is published.\

By utilizing scheduled and triggered notebooks, you can streamline your data analysis workflows, keep your datasets and visualizations up-to-date, and automate repetitive tasks. You can refer to the provided examples in the message to get inspiration and see how other Kagglers are leveraging this feature. Remember to consider the specific requirements and limitations mentioned above when setting up your pipeline. Happy automating!

2115106.content: Scheduled updates allow notebook authors to automatically re-run their notebooks at set intervals, such as daily, weekly, or monthly. This feature is useful for notebooks that depend on datasets that are updated frequently, as the notebook will automatically update when the underlying dataset is updated. Additionally, scheduled updates can be used to create, maintain, and update new datasets. Notebooks can be scheduled to update whenever a new version of the underlying dataset is published. However, there are certain limitations to this feature. Only CPU notebooks can be scheduled, and there is a limit of 5 private and 15 public notebooks that can be scheduled at any given time. Schedules also expire after a maximum of 10 runs, and for dataset update triggers, scheduled notebooks run at most once per day.

486395.content:
In the field of artificial intelligence, this is most important step for any project in AI, ML, DL, NLP.

Answering the simplest question ‚ÄúWhat is data preprocessing?‚Äù\

Processing the dataset in such a way that we could feed it to our model, so that our AI model learns best from dataset and helps in further predictions.

An AI model, being complex, is a mathematical equation which understands numbers, built upon with many mathematical tools, concepts and genius ideas.

Why data preprocessing?\

Asking ‚ÄúWhy‚Äù simplifies most of the learning process.

Datasets in the real world are not that ideal to be directly feeded into a AI model. Simply assume as they are not ready.

Lets take an example of titanic dataset.\

Problem statement : To build a predictive model that answers the question: ‚ÄúWhat sorts of people were more likely to survive?‚Äù using passenger data.

![](https://www.googleapis.com/download/storage/v1/b/kaggle-forum-message-attachments/o/inbox%2F15856017%2Fec527b94c9830990516f59e68022ea65%2FScreenshot%202024-03-24%20170225.png?generation=1711304214990052&alt=media)

Now answer my questions :

1) What can a AI model do with data like PassengerId, Name, Ticket number?\

Answer : Well the answer is very simple, AI model does nothing to with this data. Because these does not decide whether the person survives or not.

2) If you see ‚ÄúCabin‚Äù column you could see some entries as ‚ÄúNaN‚Äù. It simply means that the value is missing. Now what my AI model should do since the value is missing ?\

Answer : Yes, the answer is to handle it. But my AI model don‚Äôt know how to handle it. Handling solely depends up on the use case. We should handle those in the preprocessing step.

3) Look at the columns ‚ÄúSex‚Äù, ‚ÄúEmbarked‚Äù. They are filled with characters, string, or may be some other unrelaible datatype. Does my AI model know how to use such data for predictions?\

Answer : Absolutely no, AI model is a mathematical equation. It understands the terms only of mathematical importance.\

What‚Äôs the solution?\

Convert the categorical columns to numerical columns. It is as simple as that.

4) If I have the dataset with less number of passengers like may be 200 or 300. Is it enough to train our AI model to help with further predictions?\

The answer is that it depends. Usually we need a many datapoints to train our AI model. It also includes the step to artificially generate new datapoints. You will know about it if you follow me.

And there are many aspects of feature engineering.

#### Major steps of Preprocessing

1. Load datasets and decide which columns not at all required for our use case. Drop them from dataset. I call this step as ‚ÄúFeature selection 1‚Äù.
2. Determine the numerical columns and categorical columns.
3. Exploratory data analysis is most important step of preprocessing. I call this step as ‚ÄúKnow more about your dataset‚Äù.
4. Handle missing values by imputing mean, median, mode or any other value in place of ‚ÄúNaN‚Äù.
5. Upsample the dataset if it is unbalanced. Artificially generate more datapoints if needed.
6. Encode all the categorical features with the techniques like nominal encoding, ordinal encoding, target guided encoding.
7. Feature selection 2 : Remove the features on the basis of variance, correlation and there are many more methods.
8. Finally scale the dataset. The dataset is now ready to be feeded to AI Model.

Actually there may be some steps included in between. I have discussed the major steps. Exactly what to do in preprocessing depends on project to project and how well you have done EDA.

#### Key takeaways

Understand what is Preprocessing?\

Major steps of Preprocessing.\

You had tried to think about the answers of the questions I have asked.

486131.content:
**1.Learn the Fundamentals:**\

Start by gaining a solid understanding of the fundamentals of statistics, mathematics, and programming. This includes topics such as linear algebra, calculus, probability, and algorithms. Online courses, textbooks, and tutorials can help you build this foundation.

**2.Master Programming Languages:**\

Learn programming languages commonly used in data science such as Python or R. These languages are essential for data manipulation, analysis, and visualization. Additionally, understanding SQL for database querying can be beneficial.

**3.Get Hands-On Experience:** \

Practice your skills by working on real-world projects. You can participate in online competitions (e.g., Kaggle), contribute to open-source projects, or work on personal projects using publicly available datasets.

**4.Gain Knowledge in Machine Learning and Data Analysis:** \

Study machine learning algorithms, techniques, and methodologies. Understand how to apply them to solve different types of problems such as classification, regression, clustering, and recommendation.

**5.Explore Specialized Areas:** \

Data science encompasses various specialized areas such as natural language processing (NLP), computer vision, deep learning, and big data technologies. Explore these areas based on your interests and career goals.

**6.Earn Relevant Certifications:** \

Consider earning certifications in data science or related fields to validate your skills and knowledge. Certifications from reputable organizations or platforms like Coursera, edX, or Microsoft can enhance your credibility.

**7.Stay Updated with Industry Trends:** \

Follow blogs, forums, research papers, and conferences to stay updated with the latest trends, tools, and techniques in data science. Networking with professionals in the field can also provide valuable insights and opportunities.

**8.Build a Strong Portfolio:**\

Showcase your skills and projects through an online portfolio, GitHub repository, or personal website. A strong portfolio demonstrates your capabilities to potential employers and collaborators.

**9.Engage in Continuous Learning:**\

Data science is a rapidly evolving field, so commit to lifelong learning. Take advanced courses, attend workshops, and participate in webinars to deepen your knowledge and stay competitive.

**10.Gain Practical Experience through Internships or Freelance Work:**\

Seek internship opportunities or freelance projects to gain practical experience in applying data science techniques to real-world problems. This hands-on experience will be valuable for your career progression.

**11.Develop Soft Skills:**\

In addition to technical skills, develop soft skills such as communication, teamwork, and problem-solving. These skills are essential for collaborating with cross-functional teams and effectively conveying insights to stakeholders.

**12.Consider Advanced Education:**\

Depending on your career goals, you may consider pursuing advanced education such as a master's or Ph.D. degree in data science, statistics, computer science, or a related field.

2710319.content: So, what you can do is rename your dataset each time you update it. Like, if your dataset is called "my\_model\_results," change it to "my\_model\_results\_v1" or add the date to the name. Then, make a new dataset with the original name, "my\_model\_results." This way, you keep the old version with a new name and have a fresh dataset for the current run. If possible, try adding the new results to the original dataset instead of replacing them. This should help you keep track of all your model versions without losing any data.

485332.content:
# Exploring Data Science Job Roles and Their Life Cycle

## Description:

Are you curious about the diverse job roles within the field of data science? Join me in this exploration of the various roles, responsibilities, and career paths in data science! In this post, we'll delve into the life cycle of different data science job roles, from entry-level positions to advanced career paths. Whether you're a newcomer to the field or an experienced practitioner looking to broaden your horizons, there's something for everyone in the dynamic world of data science.

## Job Roles:

1. **Data Engineers**: Data engineers are the architects behind data infrastructure. They design, build, and maintain the systems that enable data to be collected, stored, and accessed efficiently. From data pipelines to ETL processes, data engineers play a crucial role in ensuring that data is available and ready for analysis.
2. **Data Analysts**: Data analysts are the storytellers of the data world. They sift through large datasets to uncover insights, trends, and patterns that can inform business decisions. Data analysts utilize statistical techniques and visualization tools to communicate their findings effectively to stakeholders.
3. **Data Architect**: Data architects are responsible for designing and implementing the overall structure of an organization's data ecosystem. They work closely with stakeholders to understand business requirements and develop data models and schemas that support the organization's objectives. Data architects also play a key role in ensuring data integrity, security, and compliance.
4. **Machine Learning Engineer**: Machine learning engineers specialize in building and deploying machine learning models. They work with data scientists to turn research prototypes into production-ready solutions. Machine learning engineers are proficient in programming languages like Python and have a deep understanding of algorithms, data structures, and optimization techniques.
5. **Deep Learning Engineer**: Deep learning engineers focus on developing and deploying deep neural networks for complex tasks such as image recognition, natural language processing, and speech recognition. They possess expertise in deep learning frameworks like TensorFlow and PyTorch and are skilled in training and fine-tuning deep neural networks on large-scale datasets.

## Life Cycle:

* **Entry-Level**: Entry-level positions in data science typically involve foundational tasks such as data cleaning, exploratory data analysis, and basic modeling. Individuals in these roles often work under the guidance of more experienced colleagues and have opportunities to learn and grow their skills.
* **Mid-Level**: Mid-level data scientists take on more complex projects and responsibilities, such as developing predictive models, optimizing algorithms, and collaborating with cross-functional teams. They may also mentor junior colleagues and contribute to the development of best practices within the organization.
* **Senior-Level**: Senior data scientists are seasoned professionals who provide strategic leadership and expertise in their respective domains. They are responsible for driving innovation, identifying new opportunities for leveraging data, and shaping the overall data strategy of the organization.

Join the discussion and share your insights into the fascinating world of data science job roles and their life cycle. Whether you're a data enthusiast, aspiring data scientist, or seasoned professional, there's plenty to explore and learn together on this journey!

485218.content:
There are so many tools out there that getting started in the field of data science can be both exciting and overwhelming. This is a series, so *every few days* I plan to release new content and how-to guides to enrich your journey. 

To get you started, here is a short guide that includes some data science tips and tools.

# Essential Tools for Data Science

**Jupyter Notebooks**: An open-source web application that allows you to create and share documents that contain live code, equations, visualizations, and narrative text.


```
pip install jupyterlab
content\_copy
```
**Python/R**: The most popular programming languages in data science. Python is renowned for its simplicity and readability, whereas R is specialized for statistical analysis and visualization.


```
pip install python --upgrade
content\_copy
```
**Pandas, NumPy, and Scikit-learn**: These Python libraries are staples for data manipulation, mathematical operations, and machine learning, respectively.


```
pip install pandas numpy scikit-learn
content\_copy
```
**Git and GitHub**: Version control is crucial in data science projects. Git and GitHub help manage changes and collaborate on projects with others.


```
git init
git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit"
content\_copy
```
**Visualization Tools**: Mastering data visualization is key to extracting insights and communicating your findings. Libraries like Matplotlib, Seaborn (Python), and ggplot2 (R) are widely used.


```
pip install matplotlib seaborn
content\_copy
```
The field of data science is always changing as it is essential to keep learning new methods, tools, and models. Coursera, edX, and Udacity are some of the platforms that offer data science courses. You can also keep up with the latest trends by reading research papers, going to workshops, and joining conferences.

**Focus on Fundamentals**: Before diving deep into complex models, ensure you have a strong grasp of data manipulation, visualization, and basic statistics. Python libraries like Pandas, NumPy, and Matplotlib are essential.

**Practice Regularly**: Data science is a skill honed with practice. Regularly engaging with new datasets and trying different approaches is key to improvement.

**Learn from Others**: Analyze winning solutions and discussions in competitions. Understanding others' approaches can provide new insights and techniques.

**Participate in Competitions**: Even if you don‚Äôt win, the experience gained from participating in competitions is invaluable. You‚Äôll learn to handle real-world data and deadlines.



---

\
Thanks for reading and follow me [@sahirmaharajj](https://www.kaggle.com/sahirmaharajj) for daily tips.

Backpropagation has been a game-changer in training neural networks, no doubt about it. It's like the tried-and-true foundation that's helped us achieve so much in AI. 

But you know what's exciting? The field keeps evolving, and there are always new methods popping up.

* **Boosts**: SGD and adaptive tweaks make it even stronger.
* **Cool Stuff**: Attention, capsules, and transformers are hot trends.\

Backprop is the OG, but these new tricks are pretty rad!

484666.content:
![](https://www.googleapis.com/download/storage/v1/b/kaggle-forum-message-attachments/o/inbox%2F11611801%2F3eb1781bacbb9f1ee703e275f50efb64%2F3.png?generation=1710697065113240&alt=media)

I just finished the first chapter of the book "Feature Engineering for Machine Learning: Principles and Techniques for Data Scientists," and I would like to discuss some thoughts I had along the way.

I usually create a function[1] to test a handful of models, or even apply auto-ml. When evaluating the score on both training and test data, we can infer a series of things, let's focus on the fact that the features chosen for the problem may simply not have much impact.

This is a problem if you're thinking in a data-centric analysis; however, I prefer to take this first step because I understand that if the score doesn't surpass a mere guess (50%), it leads me to believe that the features I have at hand do not reflect the nature of my problem (that is, they are inadequate). Therefore, I return to the step of selecting features and apply methods such as binning, PCA‚Ä¶ and all sorts of other strategies that I continue to learn more about. After this stage, I use random search and then grid search to save resources (first I test a sampling, select, and then test all possible ones). This process makes me proud to know that despite the mistakes, I am beginning to understand machine learning, although it may seem obvious, I believe it is a lifelong work, isn't it? It's not about models, I would say. It's about interaction, testing, reformulation, and organization so that tests are possible and controlled (like a backlog).

I conclude by saying that, not knowing where to start, first understand your problem (in competitions, using other people's notebooks is something I value highly on the platform), then using a framework that allows you to interact with the data, add a feature selection step, and then start your work in earnest.



---

## Resources

[1] Framework for testing the models


```
 def train\_eval(models, X\_train, X\_test, y\_train, y\_test):

    numeric_features = X.select_dtypes(exclude=['object']).columns
    numeric_transformer = Pipeline(
        steps=[("scaler", RobustScaler())])

    cat_features = X.select_dtypes(include=['object']).columns
    cat_transformer = Pipeline(
        steps=[("encoder", OneHotEncoder())])

    preprocessor = ColumnTransformer(
        transformers=[
            ("num", numeric_transformer, numeric_features), 
            ('cat', cat_transformer, cat_features)])

    model_score = {} 
    for name, model in models.items():

        clf = Pipeline(steps=[("preprocessor", preprocessor),
                              ("classifier", model)]) # models w/ fe

        fit_model = clf.fit(X_train, y_train)
        model_score[name] = fit_model.score(X_test, y_test)

    return f'# {model\_score}'
content\_copy
```
[2] Resources I read to write\

[Data-Centric Approach vs Model-Centric Approach in Machine Learning](https://neptune.ai/blog/data-centric-vs-model-centric-machine-learning)

[Feature Selection Methods and How to Choose Them](https://neptune.ai/blog/feature-selection-methods)



---

Thank you for coming this far. The opinion above solely reflects my perspective on what I have studied, without any intention of establishing absolute truths. As part of the learning process, I acknowledge the risk of making mistakes, but at the moment, I am confident in my words, :).

I strongly recommend reading the mentioned book. Reading is my superpower, I usually read hundreds of books per year and have frameworks that help me keep relevant information in one place where I can grasp the book's idea in seconds. I'll still talk about this because I consider that the most positive aspect of a library, as Humberto Eco well said, is the unread books (conversation for another time). Finally, I hate anything that borders on self-help, and I don't always read fiction despite having my favorites.

484500.title: Consejos para empezar en RStudio

2702132.content:
IMO, the best way to learn R is to take online courses. Most introductory R courses begin with the basics and you'll step-by-step to learn the basics of machine learning. We also also to learn math and statistics to be able to use R effectively. We have to know what to do and why we do it. 

**Courses**\

Harvard University's *Data Science Professional Certificate*\

<https://www.edx.org/certificates/professional-certificate/harvardx-data-science>

MIT's *The Analytics Edge*\

<https://www.edx.org/learn/analytics/massachusetts-institute-of-technology-the-analytics-edge>

Duke University's *Data Science with R Specialization* - This is statistics course that uses R\

<https://www.coursera.org/specializations/statistics>

Stanford's *Statistical Learning* - machine learning course\

<https://www.edx.org/learn/statistics/stanford-university-statistical-learning>

**Books**\

*R for Data Science* <https://r4ds.hadley.nz/>

*Introduction to Data Science* & *Advanced Data Science* - Textbooks for the first course listed above\

<https://juliasilge.com/>

David Robinson's YouTube channel\

<https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCeiiqmVK07qhY-wvg3IZiZQ>

The are many, many other R courses, books, tutorials, videos, and websites available online. Learn to use a Google search to find whatever you want to learn, to know, or need help with. Google is much quicker than asking questions in discussion forums. 

As a new R user, most of your errors will be due to misspelling, mis-capitalization, and mis-punctuation. Errors are part of learning. We can Google R's error messages and find answers in seconds. You also have R help within R to explain function parameters, required inputs, and the output, with examples. R Help is also available online. 

There is enough material listed above to keep you busy for a couple of years.

Hi,

Could somebody advise on the Roadmap to learning Data Science and Machine Learning in the right way?

Like, in what order should the different topics be learnt? How much of Python and Maths is needed, etc.

Thank You.
484222.title: Roadmap to Learning Data Science and Machine Learning?

2699764.content:
I suggest the below path [@taranum](https://www.kaggle.com/taranum) 

## Foundation

1. Firstly learn\*\* SQL and one among R/ python\*\* to become familiar with data wrangling and visualization. This is a pre-requisite for all projects. You may learn numpy, pandas, matplotlib, seaborn and plotly as a start-point. Also, focus on **Tableau/ Power BI** as visualization tools will help you with your upcoming interviews.

## ML classical models

1. Read ML text-books to know an algorithm, say linear regression. Then apply this algorithm on a Kaggle dataset and test your knowledge. You can replace the text book with YouTube video if you are comfortable watching YouTube to learn.
2. Then proceed to the next algorithm and repeat step2
3. Avoid deep learning algorithms till you get comfortable with ML algorithms
4. Once you are familiar with all ML algorithms, participate in Kaggle starter competitions to get an end-to-end experience of an ML project. These include- \

a. Titanic\

b. Spaceship Titanic\

c. Store Sales \

d. House Prices
5. Post this step, proceed to Kaggle playground series- apply all your past knowledge and knowledge gained from public forums to try and compete in this series

## Deep learning

1. Once this is done, you may proceed to deep learning. You may follow the below path-\

a. Learn one among tensorflow/ pytorch including data preparation and metrics\

b. Subscribe to a course (say, the Andrew Ng's DL Specialization)\

c. Practise your knowledge on Kaggle datasets and past competition data\

d. Post your solutions here and link to github
2. Proceed to complex deep learning models like LLM and GenAI at the end once you get proficient with all simple models. Rushing into this genre without clear fundamentals will harm you rather than doing good.
3. Try and build code pipelines that can be reused across assignments- take the help of GenAI tools like Mistral, Gemma, ChatGPT for the same. Having and using your own pipeline is best for upcoming competitions.

## Some useful resources

1. YouTube channels- Krish Naik, Statquest, Abhishek Thakur, Edureka (coding + ML)
2. Freecodecamp, Datacamp, W3School (coding)
3. Courses- \

a. Kaggle courses\

b. ML and DL Specialization (Coursera) and IBM ML Specialization \

c. NLP Specialization (Coursera)\

d. Computer Vision nanodegree (Udacity)\

e. GAN Specialization (Coursera)

Remember to persevere and dedicate at least 30-60 minutes per day for ML and associated tasks. Success and progression will surely follow suit. \

All the best!

> ## Level Up Your Excel Game: Unveiling Customer Acquisition Secrets üìàüîç
> 
> 
> 

Ready to transform from Excel novice to data analysis extraordinaire? Buckle up for this session, where we'll conquer powerful techniques to unlock hidden customer insights! 

**No prior Excel experience? No sweat!** This session seamlessly builds upon the foundation laid in [Data analysis in Excel- I](https://www.kaggle.com/discussions/getting-started/482931) üõ†Ô∏è

![](https://www.googleapis.com/download/storage/v1/b/kaggle-forum-message-attachments/o/inbox%2F19330665%2F62d5af083e169f34ef158d7e9594fa49%2FHow-to-add-Data-Analysis-in-Excel.jpg?generation=1710688232386758&alt=media)

Remember the bank telemarketing scenario from the last session? We're back on the mission to identify customers ripe for product acquisition through strategic telemarketing calls. Imagine the impact ‚Äì laser-targeted campaigns that maximize sales and revenue!
